I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  help  strengthen  social 
protection systems in Pacific developing member countries (DMCs). It will support the analysis 
and assessment of feasible investment options in social insurance,1 social assistance,2 and active 
labor market programs;3 capacity building to improve social protection systems and delivery of 
social protection services for vulnerable groups; and sharing of knowledge on social protection  
among Pacific DMCs.  
 
2.  The TA is in line with Strategy 2030 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), which 
underscores the importance of social protection in addressing remaining poverty and reducing 
inequalities;4 and the Pacific Approach strategy of managing risks by improving health and social 
protection services.5 It also supports the Sustainable Development Goals agenda of leaving no 
one behind. The TA is included in ADB’s regional operations business plan, 2020–2022 for 
the Pacific.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Increasing poverty, social exclusion, and vulnerability. Poverty, social exclusion, and 
vulnerability are rising in the Pacific, with about one in four Pacific Islanders living below national 
poverty lines in 2018.7 Inequality is evident in remote rural communities and among marginalized 
population groups where access to social services and job opportunities are limited. The typically 
small  and  limited  economic  base  of  Pacific  DMCs  constrains  job  opportunities.  Youth 
unemployment in 2013, for instance, averaged 23% in the region, compared with a global average 
of 13%.8 The problem is most marked for women, whose economic participation tends to be 
mostly in the informal sector—as many as 75%–90% of informal market vendors in the Pacific 
are women (footnote 7). The burden of social exclusion for women is further aggravated by high 
levels of violence against women in the region. The increasing intensity and frequency of climate- 
and  disaster-related  shocks  in  the  Pacific  heighten  vulnerability  among  the  population  by 
impacting food security and depleting savings, making it difficult for families to meet their daily 
expenditure needs.9 The recent threats of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) heightened the 
vulnerability of the Pacific given its weak health system. The impacts of COVID-19 including from

2 
economic and social disruptions will disproportionately impact the poor and vulnerable groups 
who have no means to recoup quickly. 
 
4.  Demographic  challenges.  The  region’s  changing  demographics  place  additional 
pressure on economies and societies. People aged 10–24 represent the largest population group, 
but the number and proportion of older people are rising. The number of people aged 60 years or 
older in the Pacific was about 512,000 as of 2014, and is projected to reach 1 million by 2030 and 
2 million by 2050.10 The estimated proportion of older people is more than 10% in most Pacific 
countries, and is higher in the Cook Islands and Niue as of 2014. At least 1.5 million Pacific 
Islanders, or 15% of the total Pacific population, are living with some form of disability as of 2018 
(footnote 7). The number is rising because of high rates of diabetes-related amputations and 
blindness,11 plus an aging population. These demographic changes will have implications for the 
labor force, financial markets, and traditional and formal social protection systems. 
 
5.  Traditional social protection systems under stress. Vulnerable groups rely on the 
support of strong family and community ties during times of need. However, these traditional 
social protection systems are coming under stress from rising urbanization and migration, which 
weaken community ties.12 Traditional support systems are also less effective in mitigating events 
that affect the entire community, such as economic crises and natural hazards. Susceptibility to 
natural hazards among Pacific countries, for instance, stretches the resilience of families and 
communities. Their ability to support each other is constrained by their common poverty or similar 
circumstance, hence the need for governments to play a greater role in providing social protection 
for the vulnerable, while drawing upon local social values and community systems of mutual 
assistance. The TA will consider key lessons from a previous ADB project, Social Protection of 
the Vulnerable in the Pacific,  in supporting the establishment of a formal social protection system 
in  Pacific  DMCs,  such  as  collecting  baseline  and  disaggregated  data  to  strengthen 
implementation and monitoring; exploring opportunities for volunteers to be involved; and putting 
in  place  service  standards  and  continuous  capacity  building  to  ensure  quality  of  care  for 
vulnerable groups.13 
 
6.  Inadequate formal social protection system. ADB’s Social Protection Indicator for the 
Pacific:  Assessing  Progress  reports  that  formal  social  protection  systems  are  generally 
undeveloped in the Pacific, with the exception of social insurance and provident funds that mainly 
target those with formal employment in the public sector.14 This poses further challenges with 
increased demands for social assistance under a pandemic such as COVID-19. The report found 
that average social protection expenditures in 2015 accounted for 5.3% of gross domestic product 
(GDP) per capita and favored men over women. Social insurance, particularly spending on old-
age pensions, dominates social protection spending in the region. Performance across the Pacific 
island  groups  varies,  with  Micronesia  spending  relatively  higher  on  social  insurance,  and 
Melanesia and Polynesia spending higher on social assistance.15 Spending on labor market

Where social protection exists, coverage remains weak. Social protection covered only 31.2% of 
intended beneficiaries in 2015, leaving two-thirds of eligible people without support. Social 
protection benefits also fail to reach the poor; social welfare expenditures were 1.4% of GDP per 
capita for the poor and 3.9% of GDP per capita for the nonpoor. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: government capacity and leadership in social 
protection development in selected Pacific DMCs enhanced. The TA will have the following 
outcome: social protection systems and programs strengthened in selected Pacific DMCs.16 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  The TA is designed to address piecemeal and weakly targeted social protection measures 
in the Pacific and expand social protection systems to promote sustainable support for the 
vulnerable. It will offer broad support to meet the distinct needs of the region by focusing on social 
insurance, social assistance, and active labor market programs. Although all Pacific DMCs will be 
eligible for assistance under the TA upon request, the initial focus will be on Papua New Guinea, 
Tonga, and possibly the Cook Islands, all of which have requested ADB support for strengthening 
their social protection systems. Additional support will target regional activities such as social 
protection workshops.17 Priorities will also be given to assist Pacific DMCs in responding to 
COVID-19 and other climate and disaster related shocks under all the TA outputs.   
 
9.  Output 1: Gender-responsive social protection policies and investments identified 
and prioritized. The TA  will provide technical expertise, assessments, diagnostics, and other 
analytical work to selected Pacific DMCs to (i) formulate or strengthen gender-responsive social 
protection policies and regulations suitable to the country context; and (ii) identify innovative, 
gender-responsive social protection projects and programs and assess their appropriateness for 
the selected countries. An assessment of how using technology can enhance social protection 
systems in the Pacific will draw from the experience of the Republic of Korea in applying 
technology in the provision of social services. Under output 1, the TA will provide on-the-job 
training to governments to help build a cadre of staff at the national level who are familiar with the 
critical elements of preparing social protection investments.  
 
10.  Output 2: Capacity in building social protection systems and delivery of social 
protection services for vulnerable groups improved. Under this output, the TA will build the 
capacity of selected Pacific DMCs in strengthening social protection systems and delivering 
services to vulnerable groups such as older people, people with disabilities, households headed 
by women, and poor households. The TA will examine the enabling factors and challenges to 
implementing social protection systems effectively and will assist in building government capacity  
to sustain  and improve the quality of care services for vulnerable groups. Under this output, the 
TA will collect data disaggregated by age, disability and sex to build evidence on the positive 
impacts of gender responsive design on social protection outcomes. 
 
16 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
17 Strengthening social protection for the elderly, including the delivery of elderly care services, are relevant in the Cook 
Islands and Tonga as they are among the fastest aging countries in the Pacific. Papua New Guinea, meanwhile, has 
the lowest expenditure on social protection in the Pacific.

4 
  
11.  Output 3: Social protection partnerships strengthened and knowledge products 
produced and shared among Pacific developing member countries.  Under this output, the 
TA  will help create knowledge solutions to (i) improve the design and delivery of social protection 
services in Pacific countries, and support regional conferences and workshops to promote 
knowledge and experience sharing among Pacific DMCs; and (ii) generate conference papers 
and publications on social protection as a relatively new field in the Pacific. The output will 
contribute  to  strengthening  partnerships  among  Pacific  countries  and  will  support  the 
establishment of a social protection network in the Pacific in coordination with development 
partners and other key stakeholders.18 The social protection network is envisaged to be part of 
existing government partnerships in the region to be sustainable. Output 3 will also draw from the 
experience of outputs 1 and 2 in disseminating findings and lessons. The TA will prepare a 
knowledge product dissemination plan in consultation with stakeholders and potential users of 
the information. In addition, a learning event on aged care will be held in the People’s Republic of 
China in collaboration with experts and relevant institutions in the People’s Republic of China. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund  (TASF-Others [$150,000] and TASF 6 
[$350,000]), (ii) $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and 
Knowledge Partnership Fund administered by ADB, and (iii) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund (PRC 
Fund)19 administered by ADB.20 The Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund 
will be mostly allocated to undertake prefeasibility assessments and support social protection 
policies and regulatory frameworks under output 1. The PRC Fund will be prioritized toward 
support for aged care systems and knowledge products on this topic across all outputs. The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The TA will be implemented from April 2020 to March 2025. ADB, through the Pacific 
Department, will administer the TA. The Pacific Department will work closely with the Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department to ensure complementarity with the existing TA 
on social protection (footnote 18).  The focal agency of each participating government will assist 
ADB in implementing the TA. Participating governments will provide counterpart support in the 
form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  space,  and  other  in-kind  assistance,  if  necessary.  Pacific 
Department will maintain close coordination with field offices, other development partners, and 
regional organizations in the Pacific. Disbursement of TA proceeds will follow ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The implementation 
arrangements are summarized in the table.

14.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.21 Concurrence will be sought from participating governments in the shortlisting 
of consultants. The TA will finance up to 43.0 person-months of international consulting services 
and 21.5 person-months of national consulting services. These consulting services include a pool 
of unidentified experts to be confirmed based on Pacific DMC’s request to assist with COVID-19 
and other crisis response.  ADB will use individual or consulting firm selection methods following 
the ADB Procurement Policy and its associated staff instructions. The TA requires highly qualified 
international and national experts in social protection policy and regulations, social protection 
investment planning and financing, and aged care, among others.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and 
Knowledge  Partnership  Fund;  (ii)  ADB  administering  a  portion  of  technical  assistance  not 
exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic 
of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund; and (iii) ADB providing the balance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for Strengthening Social Protection in 
the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
